body.p:
In the article “The Union of Israelites” in=
=serted in the occident for march, just reached me, I observe
a material change has taken place in Dr. Wise's original plan
for heading a meeting ? “That it shall consist of none but
delegates to be elected by any Jewish congregation in the United States”

I perceive likewise that unless 20 congregations respond to
the requisition the meeting will not take place—Permit me
a few remarks on both points. 1. I think it will be better to
afford Individuals, likewise not delegated by any congregation, the
opportunity to attend the meeting on signifying their intention to do so.

I will give my reasons for this. As every member of the Jewish
community is deeply interested in the question of a Union, all and
every one ought to have the faculty to attend such a meeting there
to consider and decide whether a union be necessary. It
may then be understood that 20 accessions to the requisition,
whether of delegates or private individuals, shall be deemed
the sufficient number, for holding the meeting, not however
limiting it to that number if more should have notified their
intention to attend it. 2. If the assembly is to be constituted
of delegates only from the congregations it may consist of many
if not of a majority of individuals knowing little of the matters to be
discussed, because appointed by congregations who at this stage
may be equally uninformed upon them. In fact, at the present

time when so little of the genuine spirit of our religion appears to
prevail, it is to be apprehended that intrigue, selfishness and
vanity may have more to do with the appointments of Delegates
than truly religious motives, unworthy means the sincerely
devoted man will scorn to employ, and unworthy motives will
not activate? him on such an occasion. He would on the contrary
be apt to keep aloof that his motives might not misconstrued.

After this, Reverend Sir; and allow such men an opportunity
to come forward voluntarily and independently to serve their people
and the cause:—if you do not I predict the affair will prove
a failure at the very out set. I learned with concern that you
had been several days confined to your room by indisposition—
but was glad to find by my son's report that you were better.

To your indisposition and incessant labours I ascribe my not
having ? favored with alive in acknowledgment of my
several late letters &c. I pray that, if you can spare time for no
more, you will write me a few lines on the subject of the 50 copies
of my letters—I am employed on the 5th with which I shall
conclude the exposition of the Divine Plan for the Government
of man, and may then return to the other points connected with
the Union of the Congregations as I situated my intention to touch
upon. My letters 3, 4, & 5 will have conducted the exposition
to the period of the sentences passed on the first pair and then
deceiver, which will disclose fully the principles upon which
the divine economy is based. All that follow, in the Bible,

in the history of your nation, and in the history of the world constitute a
series of events and circumstances connected with its operations—

It was my intention to have brought the whole subject down to the
present period but found it would trail to a much greater
length than at first contemplated. I may however resume
the subject hereafter for the occident or its reverend editor's
signifying his wish to have it to his ? Adwriter—

In my letter 2 in the occident for March a very material omission
of the word “but” has occurred. In the 1st ,, the principles to
constitute the bares? of a Union, advertising to “the effects of deviat?
from our received religious institutions &c” The compositor says
“whilst it cannot be productive of prejudicial effects to themselves
&c”—whereas I said, and I think you will find it so in the
copy sent you. “Whilst it cannot but be productive of
prejudicial effects to themselves” &c. Have the goodness, by an
arterial reference, aside Letter 3 to a note at bottom of page
to correct this mistake—AAL
